children.subject: Thank you so much for typing that out. All in all you would recommend it though? Any other upper divs you think would be beneficial besides 149?

I haven't taken EECS 151, but I took EECS 149 last semester and can share some of my thoughts about it.

Pros:

 - You get to propose and build your own embedded systems project for the entire second half of the class. This is probably the most open-ended project you can do in an EECS design class, as far as I know (the only requirement is that it builds off of some of the concepts discussed in lecture). So you can end up making something really cool that you can talk about in future interviews, etc.

- At least when I took the class, the lab GSIs were extremely friendly and helpful. You can spend a lot of time in the lab working on your project and talking to them, which will help you build academic relationships that can be very good for your future.

- Most of the projects involve taking some existing platform and building on top of it, which is pretty good experience for real-world embedded software work.

- Just being able to say that I was in a class specifically about embedded systems helped me get several interviews and eventually an internship working with embedded software.

Cons:

- The actual lecture content is pretty minimal. We did a lot of theory of finite state machines and covered some basics of networking and scheduling. However, if you've already taken CS 162, you've already learned much more about scheduling than you will in EECS 149, and I assume the same thing is true about CS 168 and networking. I've personally already forgotten most of the networking and scheduling content I learned in 149.

- Since every group in the class works on a totally different project, if you get completely stuck it's a lot harder for others to help you.

I hope this helps in some way!

history.content:
If you're interested in embedded software, 149 is obviously more relevant to that. 151 is pretty different, although it does give you some knowledge that would be good to keep in mind when working in embedded software.


If you can, I would recommend taking both. 

If you only want to take one, I would recommend 149 since it's more relevant to your interests. It also has a significantly lighter workload. The lecture wasn't really useful in my opinion (it was a lot of theory that I thought didn't really help much in the project and labs), but it gave a good overview of a bunch of different topics. The problem is that it doesn't go in depth in one thing, so it leaves you feeling kind of confused. However, the labs were really good and project was good experience since it was the first time I designed something not from a spec already given to me, and it was pretty fun. The GSIs are also the BEST that I've ever had. 

151 is also a good class though, there's *some* material that could be relevant for embedded software but mostly just good to know. The project is killer though, and might not be worth it if that's not what you're interested in. It's definitely the most time consuming project+labs I've had here.

Hello, I’m and EECS student interested in Embedded Software. I’ve taken all the CS pre-reqs as well as CS162 and was wondering if anyone could bring any insight into taking 151 vs 149. In the past I haven’t heard very great things about 149, but apparently they revamped it. Any advice is welcome, including other classes you’d recommend for someone interested in this topic.
history.subject: EECS 151 vs 149 for Embedded Software
